<item>
            <title>[IO-522] Symbolic links get followed in deleteQuietly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-522</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-168&quot; title=&quot;Symbolic links (symlinks) followed when deleting directory.&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-168&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-168&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; describes the problem. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;`deleteQuietly` will behave correctly for nested symlinks but the initial call erroneously calls `cleanDirectory`. Calling `deleteDirectory` and returning would probably be the better behaviour (analogous to `forceDelete`)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-517] FileUtils#copyDirectory cannot copy directory structure</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-517</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Have a directory structure like ..\users/domain\username and would copy the folder users with all subfolders and files. the problem now is that domain\username is a folder which is generated by ldap connecting the domain and the username with a backslash.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;java.io.IOException: Destination &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;/&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;var&lt;/span&gt;/lib/jenkins_backup_mnt/FULL-2016-11-07_11-00/users/domain\username&apos;&lt;/span&gt; directory cannot be created
at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.doCopyDirectory(FileUtils.java:1416)
at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.doCopyDirectory(FileUtils.java:1426)
at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.copyDirectory(FileUtils.java:1389)
at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.copyDirectory(FileUtils.java:1310)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-39546&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-39546&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Linux OS&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="13018938">IO-517</key>
            <summary>FileUtils#copyDirectory cannot copy directory structure</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

                            <comment id="15649525" author="yairzaslavsky" created="Wed, 9 Nov 2016 02:01:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I wrote the following test:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    public void testFoo() &lt;/p&gt;
{

        File f = new File(&quot;/tmp/yair\\directory&quot;);
        f.mkdirs();

    }

&lt;p&gt;And it manage to create me a directory called yair\directory under tmp.&lt;br/&gt;
If you look at the source code of  doCopyDirectory you will see that this is the method being used.&lt;br/&gt;
I also saw that the original reporter of the bug you stated at Jenkins thinks it might be an issue of Windows mount.&lt;br/&gt;
I think it&apos;s wort verifying.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-512] ThresholdingOutputStream.thresholdReached() results in FileNotFoundException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-512</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I upgraded from commons-io-2.0.1.jar to v2.5 (and fileupload to v1.32)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and now I get&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.io.FileNotFoundException: /usr/share/tomcat/temp/dfifp/upload_4d9f8898_1a83_4092_9070_ddf9c15de6d1_00000027.tmp (No such file or directory)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.io.FileOutputStream.open(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.io.FileOutputStream.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FileOutputStream.java:213)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.io.FileOutputStream.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FileOutputStream.java:162)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.io.output.DeferredFileOutputStream.thresholdReached(DeferredFileOutputStream.java:179)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In thresholdReached(), the prefix is null, so no temp file is created.&lt;br/&gt;
In the subsequent new FileOutputStream(outputFile), the exception is thrown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Suggested fix:&lt;br/&gt;
before new FileOutputStream(outputFile) , add&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FileUtils.forceMkdirParent(outputFile);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Similar issues reported by others:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-497&quot; title=&quot;DeferredFileOutputStream produces unhandled IOExceptions if the java.io.tmpdir is deleted&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-497&quot;&gt;IO-497&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://java.net/jira/browse/GLASSFISH-20581&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://java.net/jira/browse/GLASSFISH-20581&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://jira.sakaiproject.org/si/jira.issueviews:issue-html/SAM-1537/SAM-1537.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://jira.sakaiproject.org/si/jira.issueviews:issue-html/SAM-1537/SAM-1537.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;java8  debian&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12997325">IO-512</key>

<item>
            <title>[IO-511] After a few unit tests, a few newly created are directories not cleaned completely.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-511</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;After a few unit tests, &quot;test/io&quot; folder is not deleted. It&apos;s a bad practice in software engineering, because disk shouldn&apos;t polluted.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12983171">IO-511</key>
            <summary>After a few unit tests, a few newly created are directories not cleaned completely.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ahmetcelik">Ahmet Celik</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>pollution</label>
                            <label>test</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 25 Jun 2016 20:29:48 +0000</created>

                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="15349775" author="githubbot" created="Sat, 25 Jun 2016 20:31:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user ahmet-celik opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-509] FileUtils.readFileToString: null not usable for default encoding</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-509</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Since 2.5 FileUtils.readFileToString(File) is deprecated. readFileToString(File, Charset) should be used instead.&lt;br/&gt;
The javadoc of readFileToString(File, Charset) says that, if the charset is null, the platform default charset will be used.&lt;br/&gt;
But I cannot use readFileToString(File, null) to get that behaviour, since there also is readFileToString(File, String), so that readFileToString(File, null) is ambiguous.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12976372">IO-509</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.readFileToString: null not usable for default encoding</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="8">Not A Problem</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="wolterhis">Lars W</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 7 Jun 2016 09:22:00 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 8 Nov 2016 18:04:31 +0000</updated>

                            <comment id="15318242" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Jun 2016 09:55:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Cast the null to a Charset:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;readFileToString(File, (Charset) null)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15318267" author="wolterhis" created="Tue, 7 Jun 2016 10:36:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is there a reason for deprecating the shorter version readFileToString(File)?&lt;br/&gt;
It&apos;s not mentioned in the release notes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15318273" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Jun 2016 10:40:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It uses the default encoding.&lt;br/&gt;
This means that the behaviour is locale-dependent.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15318288" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Jun 2016 10:55:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;i.e. &lt;br/&gt;
If you want it to be portable, your code should always specify the charset and not rely on the default being correct.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

            <title>[IO-508] Veracode static  scan still shows 1 very high OS Command injection in commons-io-2.4.jar</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-508</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I cloned &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-474&quot; title=&quot; veracode scan points cross site scripting vulnerability at org/.../commons/io/FileUtils.java 2095. &quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-474&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-474&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; because we specifically upgraded the commons-io jar in our application recently to 2.4 jar and still sees, in the Veracode static scan result this one instance:  17561 189 - commons-io-2.4.jar org/.../io/FileSystemUtils.java 535 4/23/16&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Since this is going to be visible on our security reports including to potential customers, please help us at least remediate or otherwise fix in a higher version.  Thanks!  &lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[IO-502] Exceptions are suppressed incorrectly when copying files.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-502</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When copying files or directories, exceptions thrown on closing streams are suppressed incorrectly and need to be propagated to the caller.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12962251">IO-502</key>
            <summary>Exceptions are suppressed incorrectly when copying files.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="schulte77">Christian Schulte</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 25 Apr 2016 14:20:08 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 3 May 2016 18:01:59 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 17:32:47 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                    <version>2.5</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.6</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Utilities</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15257120" author="garydgregory" created="Mon, 25 Apr 2016 21:55:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In this part of the patch:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Index: src/main/java/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.java
===================================================================
--- src/main/java/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.java	(Revision 1740841)
+++ src/main/java/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.java	(Arbeitskopie)
@@ -1154,6 +1154,18 @@
                 }
                 pos += bytesCopied;
             }
+
+            output.close();
+            output = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;;
+
+            fos.close();
+            fos = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;;
+
+            input.close();
+            input = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;;
+
+            fis.close();
+            fis = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;;
         } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;finally&lt;/span&gt; {
             IOUtils.closeQuietly(output, fos, input, fis);
         }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;... some exceptions are still dropped on the floor. For example, output.close() works but fos.close() fails, then you do not &quot;see&quot; other failures. So what we really trying to do here, hide all except the 1st failure? But then, what is the proper order all the of close() calls. Should other errors then at least be printed on the console? Yikes. Sounds like a mess!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A change like this could also trip up existing apps in the case where exceptions are now thrown. But it seems quite legitimate to me... I would not care that the input fails to close but I sure do care about the output. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Perhaps, always throwing an exception on closing the output and ignoring exceptions on closing the input would be best?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thoughts?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15257219" author="schulte77" created="Mon, 25 Apr 2016 23:11:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Good questions. Closing the input silently shouldn&apos;t be an issue. Issue is the implementation of the output may make use of some kind of buffering internally and a &apos;close&apos; may trigger some kind of flushing which may produce an exception which shouldn&apos;t be suppressed. So when the &apos;close&apos; of the output throws an exception I would expect the operation to have failed and would want that exception to be propagated to the caller.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15257252" author="schulte77" created="Mon, 25 Apr 2016 23:33:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The &apos;close&apos; method of &apos;FileOutputStream&apos; translates to a call to OpenJDK&apos;s native &lt;a href=&quot;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk7u/jdk7u/jdk/file/34c594b52b73/src/solaris/native/java/io/io_util_md.c#l88&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;fileClose&lt;/a&gt; method. That will call &lt;a href=&quot;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk7u/jdk7u-dev/hotspot/file/2cd3690f644c/src/share/vm/prims/jvm.cpp#l2642&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;JVM_Close&lt;/a&gt; leading to the operating system&apos;s C libraries &apos;close&apos; function getting called. Definitely want any error that function returns to be propagated as an exception to the caller. It&apos;s completely operating system dependent. On my system the manpage of close states:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;ERRORS
     close() will fail if:

     [EBADF]            d is not an active descriptor.
     [EINTR]            An interrupt was received.
     [EIO]              An I/O error occurred while writing to the file system.
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Not suppressing any of these errors silently should do. I think closing a channel obtained from a stream will also close the stream internally. I do not know if that is specified behaviour or just an implementation detail of e.g. OpenJDK.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15257265" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 25 Apr 2016 23:46:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Seems to me that the suggested patch is fine.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It closes the output objects first, so those take precedence over input.&lt;br/&gt;
It also closes the channel before the stream.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is there really any point in trying to capture further close errors once the first error has occurred?&lt;br/&gt;
Would that provide any useful information?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15259213" author="garydgregory" created="Tue, 26 Apr 2016 23:56:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=schulte77&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;schulte77&quot;&gt;Christian Schulte&lt;/a&gt;,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The patch causes NPE. Fixed is subsequent commit.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please verify and close.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thank you!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gary&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15260370" author="schulte77" created="Wed, 27 Apr 2016 16:02:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Getting&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;testGetFreeSpace_String(org.apache.commons.io.FileSystemUtilsTestCase)  Time elapsed: 0.277 sec  &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; ERROR!
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unsupported operating system
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceOS(FileSystemUtils.java:271)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileSystemUtils.freeSpace(FileSystemUtils.java:143)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileSystemUtilsTestCase.testGetFreeSpace_String(FileSystemUtilsTestCase.java:71)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Dockerfile&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FROM fedora:21&lt;br/&gt;
RUN yum update -y&lt;br/&gt;
RUN yum install -y java-1.8.0-openjdk unzip&lt;br/&gt;
RUN yum install -y maven&lt;br/&gt;
COPY commons-io-2.4-src.zip commons-io-2.4-src.zip&lt;br/&gt;
RUN unzip commons-io-2.4-src.zip&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd commons-io-2.4-src &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn initialize&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd commons-io-2.4-src &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn test-compile&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd commons-io-2.4-src &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn install&lt;br/&gt;
RUN chmod -R 755 /root&lt;br/&gt;
CMD /bin/bash&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;==&lt;br/&gt;
Did a second run with commons-io.2,5&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Failed tests: &lt;br/&gt;
  FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase.testThrowsOnNullList:109 expected IOException&lt;br/&gt;
  FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase.testThrowsOnCannotDeleteFile:129 expected IOException&lt;br/&gt;

  FileFilterTestCase.testCanWrite:1005-&amp;gt;assertFiltering:64 Filter(File) org.apache.commons.io.filefilter.CanWriteFileFilter not false for /root/commons-io-2.5-src/test/io/read-only-file2.txt expected:&amp;lt;false&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;true&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Tests run: 1157, Failures: 4, Errors: 0, Skipped: 4&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Dockerfile contents&lt;br/&gt;
FROM fedora:21&lt;br/&gt;
RUN yum update -y&lt;br/&gt;
RUN yum install -y java-1.8.0-openjdk unzip&lt;br/&gt;
RUN yum install -y maven&lt;br/&gt;
RUN yum install -y wget&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root &amp;amp;&amp;amp; wget &lt;a href=&quot;http://apache.parentingamerica.com//commons/io/source/commons-io-2.5-src.zip&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://apache.parentingamerica.com//commons/io/source/commons-io-2.5-src.zip&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root &amp;amp;&amp;amp; unzip commons-io-2.5-src.zip&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root &amp;amp;&amp;amp; cd commons-io-2.5-src &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn initialize&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root &amp;amp;&amp;amp; cd commons-io-2.5-src &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn test-compile&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root &amp;amp;&amp;amp; cd commons-io-2.5-src &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn install&lt;br/&gt;
RUN chmod -R 755 /root&lt;br/&gt;
CMD /bin/bash&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;command: $docker build .&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;==&lt;br/&gt;
Debian Jessie, JDK 7 also fails with code coming from trunk&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Failed tests: &lt;br/&gt;
  FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase.testThrowsOnNullList:109 expected IOException&lt;br/&gt;
  FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase.testThrowsOnCannotDeleteFile:129 expected IOException&lt;br/&gt;
  FileFilterTestCase.testCanRead:984-&amp;gt;assertFiltering:64 Filter(File) org.apache.commons.io.filefilter.AndFileFilter not true for /root/commons-io/test/io/read-only-file1.txt expected:&amp;lt;true&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;false&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  FileFilterTestCase.testCanWrite:1005-&amp;gt;assertFiltering:64 Filter(File) org.apache.commons.io.filefilter.CanWriteFileFilter not false for /root/commons-io/test/io/read-only-file2.txt expected:&amp;lt;false&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;true&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
FROM debian:8.4&lt;br/&gt;
CMD /bin/bash&lt;br/&gt;
RUN apt-get update -y&lt;br/&gt;
RUN apt-get install -y openjdk-7-jdk openjdk-7-jre unzip maven wget subversion&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root &amp;amp;&amp;amp; svn checkout -r 1740549 &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/commons/proper/io/trunk&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/commons/proper/io/trunk&lt;/a&gt; /root/commons-io&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root/commons-io &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn initialize&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root/commons-io &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn test-compile&lt;br/&gt;
RUN cd /root/commons-io &amp;amp;&amp;amp; mvn install&lt;br/&gt;
RUN chmod -R 755 /root&lt;br/&gt;
======================&lt;br/&gt;
All the above are where the users home directory is NFS mounted.&lt;br/&gt;
I retried 2.5-src on a machine where the home directory for the users was local and it made no difference.&lt;br/&gt;
Using Fedora23 in VirtualBox on Windows 7.&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="15252652" author="joehni" created="Thu, 21 Apr 2016 20:39:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Works for me. Downloaded commons-io-2.4-src.zip from Apache. Unzipped archive and started Maven from archive root with&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, it is not OpenJDK 8, it&apos;s not Linux in general nor is it the original zipped archive.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Actually I tested commons-io 2.4 befor voting for the release. I used the tarball of the sources and built it with each JDK of my zoo. This includes the Oracle versions 6-9, IBM 6+7, and OpenJDK 6+7 (8 is new). All tests passed for every JDK (except IBM 6 with known UTF-16 problems):&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.jakarta.commons.devel/130600&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.jakarta.commons.devel/130600&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-499] FilenameUtils.directoryContains(String, String) gives false positive when two directories exist with equal prefixes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-499</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In a folder layout as such:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;/foo/a.txt
/foo2/b.txt
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The result of invoking directoryContains is wrong:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;FilenameUtils.directoryContains(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/foo&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/foo2/b.txt&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// returns &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;even if &quot;/foo&quot; and &quot;/foo2/b.txt&quot; are the canonical paths, they start with the same characters, and the current implementation of the method fails.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As workaround we are currently appending a path separator &apos;/&apos; to the first argument.&lt;br/&gt;
It is noteworthy that the current implementation of FileUtils.directoryContains() reveals this issue because it uses the File.getCanonicalPath() to obtain the String paths of &quot;/foo&quot; and &quot;/foo2/b.txt&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12939560">IO-499</key>
            <summary>FilenameUtils.directoryContains(String, String) gives false positive when two directories exist with equal prefixes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="fedechicco">Federico Bonelli</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 16 Feb 2016 17:27:12 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 23 Apr 2017 15:12:45 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>2.4</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15519730" author="githubbot" created="Sat, 24 Sep 2016 22:24:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user cagdasyelen opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/pull/20&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/pull/20&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-499&quot; title=&quot;FilenameUtils.directoryContains(String, String) gives false positive when two directories exist with equal prefixes&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-499&quot;&gt;IO-499&lt;/a&gt; FilenameUtils.directoryContains false positive issue &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-499&quot; title=&quot;FilenameUtils.directoryContains(String, String) gives false positive when two directories exist with equal prefixes&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-499&quot;&gt;IO-499&lt;/a&gt; bug has been fixed. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    The old version was looking at if the child canonical path string starts with the parent&apos;s. &lt;br/&gt;
    However, it fails in the case of:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    .../top/foo&lt;br/&gt;
    .../top/foo2/b.txt&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    since the directory path of b.txt starts with the same directory path with the one above even though the second one is a different directory(foo2). This issue is resolved by comparing the path strings of foo and foo2. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/cagdasyelen/commons-io&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/cagdasyelen/commons-io&lt;/a&gt; io499-fix&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/pull/20.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/pull/20.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #20&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit fd95ccde6310bfee7314744d879c597882cb3381&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Cagdas Yelen &amp;lt;cagdas@utexas.edu&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2016-09-24T22:21:37Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-499&quot; title=&quot;FilenameUtils.directoryContains(String, String) gives false positive when two directories exist with equal prefixes&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-499&quot;&gt;IO-499&lt;/a&gt; FilenameUtils.directoryContains false positive issue is resolved&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-498] FileUtils.directoryContains(File, File) returns wrong results when the file name contains unreadable characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-498</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When testing for FileUtils.directoryContains(File, File) on a file which is in fact contained in the given directory but has odd characters in the name, the method returns wrong results.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This file:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;File name&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;bof@testcorso2015:~/tmp/test$ ls col* | xxd
0000000: 636f 6c74 e00a                           colt..
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;fails to be recognized as belonging to the current directory in this simple snippet of code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Snippet&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;File[] files = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; File(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;.&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).listFiles();
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt;(File f : files){
     &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;contains &quot;&lt;/span&gt; + f + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot; = &quot;&lt;/span&gt; + FileUtils.directoryContains(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; File(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;.&quot;&lt;/span&gt;), f));
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;linux&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12938802">IO-498</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.directoryContains(File, File) returns wrong results when the file name contains unreadable characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="fedechicco">Federico Bonelli</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 12 Feb 2016 13:11:04 +0000</created>

                            <comment id="15144797" author="fedechicco" created="Fri, 12 Feb 2016 16:27:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is it worth noticing that in this case the method fails because of what I think being a JVM bug.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The snippet&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;File[] files = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; File(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;.&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).listFiles();
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt;(File f : files){
     &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;exists: &quot;&lt;/span&gt; + f.exists());
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;shows that with an ill formed name as the one I&apos;m using the File class is not able to work properly.&lt;br/&gt;
The same file object returned by listFiles() is said to be unexistant.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15144908" author="b.eckenfels" created="Fri, 12 Feb 2016 17:31:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is this on a UTF8 system? I think with an ISO88591 native name encoding it should be binary transparent.&lt;br/&gt;
But in any case nothing Commons IO can do about. I propose to close it.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://jonisalonen.com/2012/java-and-file-names-with-invalid-characters/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jonisalonen.com/2012/java-and-file-names-with-invalid-characters/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15144930" author="fedechicco" created="Fri, 12 Feb 2016 17:39:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes it is on a UTF8 system.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m afraid you are right, this is nothing we can solve in the Commons IO.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I wish this was fixable, but I agree to close it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-497] DeferredFileOutputStream produces unhandled IOExceptions if the java.io.tmpdir is deleted</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-497</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In the event that the Java temporary directory is deleted prior to the DeferredFileOutputStream trying to use it, the stream will throw one of two different IOExceptions (depending on how the Stream was constructed). &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This may sound like an unrealistic use-case at first, but it is legitimate as one of my company&apos;s applications encountered it after the underlying operating system (CentOS) automatically purged the contents of its tmp directory. (The application uses Commons FileUpload, which invokes DeferredFileOutputStream and does not handle the error itself.) Our current work-around is to restart the server when this happens, but we feel that the underlying library should perhaps be intelligent enough to recover from such an error.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Additionally, it seems an awkward experience that two different errors are produced based on how the stream was constructed. One approach produces a FileNotFoundException while the other produces a plain IOException. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A small maven project containing a single JUnit test that highlights the error will be attached (see &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12783728/dfos-bug.tar.gz&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;dfos-bug.tar.gz&lt;/a&gt;). &lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;unix-like operating systems where temporary disk storage is routinely purged; CentOS specifically&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12933229">IO-497</key>
            <summary>DeferredFileOutputStream produces unhandled IOExceptions if the java.io.tmpdir is deleted</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="nbyrd">Nicholas Byrd</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 22 Jan 2016 01:18:51 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 13 Sep 2017 18:42:45 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>2.4</version>
                                                    <component>Streams/Writers</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15111735" author="nbyrd" created="Fri, 22 Jan 2016 01:22:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attached you will find the small Maven project that highlights this bug. Please see the &quot;TestDeferredFileOutputStream.java&quot; file. The tarball contains a README file documenting how to run the tests from the command line.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively, if you would like the file by itself, I will paste it here:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.io.IOUtils;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.io.output.DeferredFileOutputStream;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.junit.Before;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.junit.Test;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.io.*;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.util.Random;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; org.junit.Assume.assumeFalse;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; org.junit.Assume.assumeTrue;

/**
 * Tests the Commons IO {@link org.apache.commons.io.output.DeferredFileOutputStream}.
 */
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;TestDeferredFileOutputStream {
    /**
     * The threshold value that will be used to construct
     * {@link org.apache.commons.io.output.DeferredFileOutputStream}s. 10KiB was chosen because
     * &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt; value is used in the Commons FileUpload library.
     */
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; THRESHOLD = 10240;

    /**
     * Will hold a sizable chunk of data that the test can pass through streams.
     */
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;byte&lt;/span&gt;[] data;

    /**
     * Sets up the test fixture, creating some data to work with and ensuring that
     * the tmpdir is usable.
     */
    @Before
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void setup() {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Create a (fairly large) chunk of data &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; the test to work with.
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Must be larger than the stream&apos;s threshold, so that
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// org.apache.commons.io.output.ThresholdingOutputStream.thresholdReached() is invoked.
&lt;/span&gt;        data = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;byte&lt;/span&gt;[2*THRESHOLD];
        Random rng = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Random(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.currentTimeMillis());
        rng.nextBytes(data);

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// ensure that the java tmpdir exists between tests
&lt;/span&gt;        File tmpDir = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; File(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.getProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;java.io.tmpdir&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (!tmpDir.isDirectory()) {
            assumeFalse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;tmpDir exists but is actually a file&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, tmpDir.exists());
            assumeTrue(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;able to rebuild tmpdir&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, tmpDir.mkdir());
        }
        assumeTrue(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;can write to tmpDir&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, tmpDir.canWrite());
        assumeTrue(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;can read from tmpDir&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, tmpDir.canRead());
    }

    /**
     * This is a basic test of the DeferredFileOutputStream. This is not expected to fail.
     * @&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException in the event that something goes horribly wrong.
     */
    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testStream() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException {
        File someFile = File.createTempFile(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;something&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;tmp&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt; (InputStream is = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ByteArrayInputStream(data)) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt; (OutputStream dfos = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; DeferredFileOutputStream(THRESHOLD, someFile)) {
                IOUtils.copy(is, dfos);
            }
        }
    }

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// This test fails due to an uncaught FileNotFoundException that bubbles
&lt;/span&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// up from DeferredFileOutputStream.
&lt;/span&gt;    /**
     * Tests what happens &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; the tmpDir gets deleted before the DeferredFileOutputStream tries to use it.
     */
    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testStreamWithDelete() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException {
        File someFile = File.createTempFile(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;something2&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;.tmp&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
        File tmpDir = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; File(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.getProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;java.io.tmpdir&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
        FileUtils.deleteDirectory(tmpDir);

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt; (InputStream is = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ByteArrayInputStream(data)) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt; (OutputStream dfos = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; DeferredFileOutputStream(THRESHOLD, someFile)) {
                IOUtils.copy(is, dfos);
            }
        }
    }

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// This test fails due to an uncaught IOException bubbling up from DeferredFileOutputStream.
&lt;/span&gt;
    /**
     * Tests what happens &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; the tmpDir is not usable due to being deleted. Uses
     * the non-{@link java.io.File} constructor when creating the
     * {@link org.apache.commons.io.output.DeferredFileOutputStream}.
     */
    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testStreamWithDeleteAlternative() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException {
        File tmpDir = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; File(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.getProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;java.io.tmpdir&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
        FileUtils.deleteDirectory(tmpDir);

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt; (InputStream is = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ByteArrayInputStream(data)) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt; (OutputStream dfos = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; DeferredFileOutputStream(THRESHOLD, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;something3&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;.tmp&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, tmpDir)) {
                IOUtils.copy(is, dfos);
            }
        }
    }
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15112128" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 22 Jan 2016 09:09:21 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;One approach produces a FileNotFoundException while the other produces a plain IOException.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These are both IOExceptions, so that does not seem unreasonable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As to the behaviour of CentOS - I understand why it might delete old files from the temporary directory, but it does not seem reasonable to delete the directory entirely.&lt;br/&gt;
Surely that will cause problems for lots of applications, not just the IO class? What happens when the next app wants to create a temporary file?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note: assuming that CentOS does not delete the temporary directory if it contains any active files, a work-round for your case might be to have a background task which updates a dummy file in the temporary directory.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15112974" author="nbyrd" created="Fri, 22 Jan 2016 20:05:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;@Sebb, I think you bring up a good point. I don&apos;t have any reason to believe that the entire directory is being deleted, but it is definitely being cleared on a regular basis (deleting all files and sub directories). Attached, you will find a &quot;v2&quot; of the test package which more closely emulates this behavior. The exceptions still exist in these cases.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Additionally, I am attaching an example stack trace from our production application where these issues started popping up. (Just for reference, the version of Spring-Web we&apos;re using is 3.1.2-RELEASE; however the file management is still all being performed by Commons-FileUpload and Commons-IO.)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15113227" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 22 Jan 2016 22:21:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It still does not make sense to purge the contents which are clearly still being used.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Are you sure that this is not a faulty cron job?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not convinced that this is something that the IO library either should (or even could) handle.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15113364" author="nbyrd" created="Fri, 22 Jan 2016 23:59:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the input, &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;~sebb@apache.org&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;. I have forwarded your question (asking exactly how tmpfs is being managed) to my company&apos;s technical operations manager and will respond once I have the answer.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15421172" author="hauser@acm.org" created="Mon, 15 Aug 2016 15:52:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;see also &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-512&quot; title=&quot;ThresholdingOutputStream.thresholdReached() results in FileNotFoundException&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-512&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-512&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16165094" author="nbyrd" created="Wed, 13 Sep 2017 18:42:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the update, &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=ralfhauser&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;ralfhauser&quot;&gt;Ralf Hauser&lt;/a&gt;. I&apos;ve retried the attached unit tests using the latest commons-io 2.6-SNAPSHOT build. The &quot;testStreamWithDelete&quot; test now passes, but the &quot;testStreamWithDeleteAlternative&quot; test still fails. So it would seem that &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-512&quot; title=&quot;ThresholdingOutputStream.thresholdReached() results in FileNotFoundException&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-512&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-512&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; is potentially only a partial fix at this point. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-496] javadoc of copyDirectory misleading</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-496</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;javadoc of copyDirectory states:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This method copies the specified directory and all its child directories and files to the specified destination. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In fact it only copies the children of the directory (contrary to copyDirectoryToDirectory).&lt;/p&gt;


</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12929028">IO-496</key>
            <summary>javadoc of copyDirectory misleading</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

            <title>[IO-494] Mismatch return type in api docs of class DirectoryWalker.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-494</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In the api docs of class org.apache.commons.io.DirectoryWalker&amp;lt;T&amp;gt;, topic of 3.1 External / Multi-threaded.Method handleIsCancelled in demo code returns boolean but with a void return type.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12928059">IO-494</key>
            <summary>Mismatch return type in api docs of class DirectoryWalker.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[IO-492] Typo: In an IOUtils.java comment it says &quot;focussed&quot; instead of &quot;focused&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-492</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;See here: &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/blob/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/io/IOUtils.java#L101&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/blob/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/io/IOUtils.java#L101&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12924673">IO-492</key>
            <summary>Typo: In an IOUtils.java comment it says &quot;focussed&quot; instead of &quot;focused&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>

<item>
            <title>[IO-491] Copying *.app corrupts the file</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-491</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When ever I try to copy a *.app to a folder, *.app corrupts completely. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Mac OS 10.11.2&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12924228">IO-491</key>
            <summary>Copying *.app corrupts the file</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/blocker.svg">Blocker</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="akshaybabloo">Akshay Raj Gollahalli</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>patch</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 24 Dec 2015 22:02:08 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 16 Feb 2017 18:07:05 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 16 Feb 2017 18:07:01 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                                    <component>Streams/Writers</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15071285" author="garydgregory" created="Thu, 24 Dec 2015 23:13:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Kinda hard to help you without a code example.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15071340" author="akshaybabloo" created="Fri, 25 Dec 2015 03:17:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ok, So I created a JavaFX application and packed it natively for Mac OS X. This native app is called &quot;JCal.app&quot;. It&apos;s basically a directory for Mac (as far as I know). When you open it&apos;s content (right click -&amp;gt; Show Contents) and go to &quot;JCal.app/MacOS/&quot; you will find a file called JCal (which is an Unix Executable file).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Now lets say that this particular is in my downloads folder and I want to copy it to Applications folder, I would do the following &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FileUtils.copyDirectoryToDirectory(FileUtils.getFile(System.getProperty(&quot;user.home&quot;) + &quot;/Downloads/JCal.app&quot;), FileUtils.getFile(&quot;/Applications/&quot;));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;which should copy the complete directory (in this case JCal.app) to Applications folder. Now the directory is getting copied but which this is happening the Unix executable file gets corrupted and turned in a known text file with question marks and symbols. This should not happen.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15125895" author="kinow" created="Mon, 1 Feb 2016 07:42:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Couldn&apos;t reproduce it with my current environment (below).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;java version &quot;1.8.0_66&quot;
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_66-b17)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.66-b17, mixed mode)

Apache Maven 3.3.9 (bb52d8502b132ec0a5a3f4c09453c07478323dc5; 2015-11-11T05:41:47+13:00)
Maven home: /home/kinow/Development/java/apache-maven-3.3.9
Java version: 1.8.0_66, vendor: Oracle Corporation
Java home: /home/kinow/Development/java/jdk1.8.0_66/jre
Default locale: en_NZ, platform encoding: UTF-8
OS name: &quot;linux&quot;, version: &quot;3.19.0-47-generic&quot;, arch: &quot;amd64&quot;, family: &quot;unix&quot;

kinow@localhost:~$ uname -a
Linux localhost 3.19.0-47-generic #53~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Mon Jan 18 16:09:14 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
kinow@localhost:~$ cat /etc/lsb-release 
DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu
DISTRIB_RELEASE=14.04
DISTRIB_CODENAME=trusty
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION=&quot;Ubuntu 14.04.3 LTS&quot;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Created a folder ~/DIR1.app, with some content in it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;kinow@localhost:~$ mkdir ~/DIR1.app
kinow@localhost:~$ cd ~/DIR1.app
kinow@localhost:~/DIR1$ touch date.txt
kinow@localhost:~/DIR1$ date &amp;gt; date.txt
kinow@localhost:~/DIR1$ cat date.txt 
Mon Feb  1 20:23:11 NZDT 2016
kinow@localhost:~/DIR1$ md5sum date.txt 
3324a7961efd23aaa09dc3c6e79ee4c8  date.txt
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And them copied it to another folder with the example provided, as follows.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; void main(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] args) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {        FileUtils.copyDirectoryToDirectory(FileUtils.getFile(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.getProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;user.home&quot;&lt;/span&gt;) + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/DIR1.app&quot;&lt;/span&gt;),
                FileUtils.getFile(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/tmp/&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And the folder and file created were both correctly copied, with no corruption.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;kinow@localhost:~/DIR1.app$ ls /tmp/DIR1.app/
date.txt
kinow@localhost:~/DIR1.app$ cat /tmp/DIR1.app/
kinow@localhost:~/DIR1.app$ cat /tmp/DIR1.app/date.txt 
Mon Feb  1 20:23:11 NZDT 2016
kinow@localhost:~/DIR1.app$ md5sum /tmp/DIR1.app/date.txt 
3324a7961efd23aaa09dc3c6e79ee4c8  /tmp/DIR1.app/date.txt
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The ~/DIR1.app folder was created using the default umask and had the permission to 0755. But even after changing the mode to 0777, and repeating it, the code worked as expected.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Would be nice to have an attachment (.zip or .app maybe) and if someone with a Mac could test it too. It could be due to some other process using the file, or some other thing related to the reporter environment.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Hope that helps.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-489] EmptyFileFilter doesn&apos;t work on directories using FileUtils.listFilesAndDirs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-489</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;My directory tree:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;~/ioutils&amp;gt; ls -lhR
.:
total 20K
drwxrwxr-x 2 jorge jorge 4.0K Dec  2 14:54 empty/
drwxrwxr-x 2 jorge jorge 4.0K Dec  2 14:54 not-empty/
-rw-rw-r-- 1 jorge jorge    5 Dec  2 15:02 text.txt

./empty:
total 0

./not-empty:
total 12K
-rw-rw-r-- 1 jorge jorge 5 Dec  2 14:54 text.txt
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;When I execute:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;File baseDir = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; File(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/home/jorge/ioutils&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
IOFileFilter emptyDirectoriesFilter = FileFilterUtils.and(
  DirectoryFileFilter.DIRECTORY, 
  EmptyFileFilter.EMPTY
);
FileUtils.listFilesAndDirs(baseDir, emptyDirectoriesFilter, TrueFileFilter.TRUE);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I obtain:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;[/home/jorge/ioutils, /home/jorge/ioutils/not-empty, /home/jorge/ioutils/empty]
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Issue:  &lt;tt&gt;/home/jorge/ioutils/not-empty&lt;/tt&gt; directory is included in the result.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But If I execute&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;baseDir.list(emptyDirectoriesFilter);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;the correct result includes &lt;tt&gt;/home/jorge/empty&lt;/tt&gt; directory.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Distributor ID:	Ubuntu&lt;br/&gt;
Description:	Ubuntu 12.04.5 LTS&lt;br/&gt;
Release:	12.04&lt;br/&gt;
Codename:	precise&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12917665">IO-489</key>
            <summary>EmptyFileFilter doesn&apos;t work on directories using FileUtils.listFilesAndDirs</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="Giorgy">Jorge Spinsanti</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 2 Dec 2015 18:11:15 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 8 Nov 2016 18:04:28 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 3 Dec 2015 13:13:23 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                                    <component>Filters</component>
                        <due></due>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15037763" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 3 Dec 2015 13:13:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The Javadoc for FileUtils.listFilesAndDirs says &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Parameters:&lt;br/&gt;
    directory - the directory to search in&lt;br/&gt;
    fileFilter - filter to apply when finding files.&lt;br/&gt;
    dirFilter - optional filter to apply when finding subdirectories. If this parameter is null, subdirectories will not be included in the search. Use TrueFileFilter.INSTANCE to match all directories. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you want to match only some sub-directories you have to provide the appropriate filter.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-io/javadocs/api-2.4/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.html#listFilesAndDirs%28java.io.File,%20org.apache.commons.io.filefilter.IOFileFilter,%20org.apache.commons.io.filefilter.IOFileFilter%29&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-io/javadocs/api-2.4/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.html#listFilesAndDirs%28java.io.File,%20org.apache.commons.io.filefilter.IOFileFilter,%20org.apache.commons.io.filefilter.IOFileFilter%29&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-485] org.apache.commons.io.output.LockableFileWriter#append() overwrites rather than appends when two instance invoke this method to a same file.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-485</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;LockableFileWriter fw0 = new LockableFileWriter(&quot;/tmp/push_failure.log&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        fw0.append(&quot;hello,\n&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        fw0.flush();&lt;br/&gt;
        fw0.close();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;LockableFileWriter fw1 = new LockableFileWriter(&quot;/tmp/push_failure.log&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        fw1.append(&quot;world.&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        fw1.flush();&lt;br/&gt;
        fw1.close();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;then the file&apos;s content is &quot;world.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Mac OSX, jdk1.8&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12857143">IO-485</key>
            <summary>org.apache.commons.io.output.LockableFileWriter#append() overwrites rather than appends when two instance invoke this method to a same file.</summary>

<item>
            <title>[IO-483] getPrefixLength return -1 if unix file contains colon</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-483</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A simple&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; prefixLength = FilenameUtils.getPrefixLength(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/:foo/bar&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;return &lt;tt&gt;-1&lt;/tt&gt;, but &lt;tt&gt;0&lt;/tt&gt; was expected. The path is absolutely valid for unix systems.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12851327">IO-483</key>
            <summary>getPrefixLength return -1 if unix file contains colon</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="kinow">Bruno P. Kinoshita</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tril">Tristan Lins</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 4 Aug 2015 07:35:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 2 Dec 2016 03:15:46 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 2 Dec 2016 03:15:45 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                                    <component>Utilities</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>4</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14679975" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 10 Aug 2015 11:40:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Or indeed &quot;/:/bar&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14679983" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 10 Aug 2015 11:47:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;However, in both cases I think the expected length should be 1, not 0, as the prefix will be &quot;/&quot;, not &quot;&quot; (these are absolute pathnames)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15125914" author="kinow" created="Mon, 1 Feb 2016 08:05:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like FilenameUtils#getPrefixLength is finding the colon character in the second position, and then it gets the previous character (around line 660 and 666 r1727892) and checks the following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;ch0 = &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Character&lt;/span&gt;.toUpperCase(ch0);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (ch0 &amp;gt;= &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;A&apos;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;&amp;amp; ch0 &amp;lt;= &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;Z&apos;&lt;/span&gt;) {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (len == 2 || isSeparator(filename.charAt(2)) == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; 2;
    }
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; 3;
}
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; NOT_FOUND;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The ch0 &amp;gt;= &apos;A&apos; &amp;amp;&amp;amp; ch0 &amp;lt;= &apos;Z&apos; is evaluated to false, since ch0 is &apos;/&apos;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maybe this issue could be fixed by updating the Javadoc to state that one of the valid prefixes is a case insensitive character, from a to z, followed by a colon?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15519519" author="githubbot" created="Sat, 24 Sep 2016 19:37:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user marko-vasic opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/pull/19&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/pull/19&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-483&quot; title=&quot;getPrefixLength return -1 if unix file contains colon&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-483&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-483&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; FilenameUtils.getPrefixLength fix for unix files/folders starting with colon&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    FilenameUtils.getPrefixLength now works correctly for unix files/folder that are in the root folder and start with colons&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/marko-vasic/commons-io&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/marko-vasic/commons-io&lt;/a&gt; master&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/pull/19.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-io/pull/19.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #19&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit a7bd568249f9ec20b69b2a700da6a0648e93a842&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-481] org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils#waitFor waits too long</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-481</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The timing algorithm is basically broken, since Thread.sleep is imprecise. There is also a counter error in the looping code. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following testcase will never run in less than 4 seconds on my machine&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  public void testRealWallTime() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        long start = System.currentTimeMillis();
        FileUtils.waitFor(new File(&quot;&quot;), 2);
        System.out.println(&quot;elapsed = &quot; + (System.currentTimeMillis() - start));
    }</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12839199">IO-481</key>
            <summary>org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils#waitFor waits too long</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
